explanation:
You must examine the definitions (and any macros/inlines) of the following symbols because MISRA Rule (no language extensions) requires checking whether any called/used symbols expand to or are implemented with compiler extensions (GCC/Clang builtins, __attribute__, inline asm, statement-expressions, typeof, anonymous structs/unions, reserved double-underscore identifiers, etc.). For each symbol: 

- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static: used directly to build the response; its implementation might be a macro/inline that uses compiler-specific builtins or attributes. 
- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls: callee of the above (seen in call graph); could introduce extensions when inlined/implemented. 
- MHD_add_response_header: called from target; frequently implemented as a macro-wrapper or inline helper — its definition could use language extensions. 
- MHD_queue_response: called from target; its implementation may be inline or macro and could use extensions affecting compliance. 
- MHD_destroy_response: called from target; call graph shows it (or its implementation) invokes __builtin_unreachable — an explicit compiler builtin/extension; you must inspect its definition to confirm usage and context. 
- __builtin_unreachable: present in the call graph as a callee of MHD_destroy_response; it is a compiler builtin (extension) and must be flagged if reachable/used. 
- MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_TYPE, MHD_HTTP_NOT_FOUND, MHD_NO: these macros/constants are used in the target; they may be defined with extension-bearing constructs (macros with statement-expressions, attributes, or weird token-pasting). 
- enum MHD_Result: return type of the function — its definition must be reviewed for any compiler-specific extensions applied to the enum (attributes, underlying type specifiers, or non-standard annotations). 
- struct MHD_Response, struct MHD_Connection: pointer types used in the function — their definitions may include anonymous/unnamed fields, compiler-specific alignment/packing attributes, or other extensions.

Provide the source/header definitions for these symbols to the next analyzer so it can determine whether any language/compiler-specific extensions are used either in their definitions or inlined expansions.
